title: Has a president ever won an election by one vote? - Quora

response.answer_text: In a sense, it has happened at least three times — and each time, due to the electoral college… not the electoral college itself, but by the vote of a small panel or committee that made a ruling on the elections. Although… if you do count the electoral college, George W. Bush won the electoral college with just 1 elector to spare. Which means that if Gore could’ve convinced just 2 electors to switch from Bush to him, he would’ve become president. I think he correctly concluded, though, that wasn’t going to work, no matter how many things had gone wrong with the Florida 2000 presidential election… Because you see, the 538 electors are not a group of “wise people” as Hamilton might have wanted — they are chosen because they are party hacks. So, those Republican party hacks were never, ever going to vote for Gore. Now, as to the other cases…. Going back to 2000 again. There are arguments as to who really won Florida, had the recount continued. Some say that Bush would’ve won anyway. However, what did end the recount, essentially declaring Bush the winner, was the 5–4 decision in Bush v. Gore from the Supreme Court. That can be considered a case where one vote made someone president. An even worse case happened in the infamous Tilden v. Hayes election (1876). Democrat Tilden won the popular vote by 3%, a significant margin. He also won the electoral college with 19 elector votes to spare. BUT THEN… The Republicans contested several of the states… enough states to potentially switch 20 electoral votes, precisely enough to flip the election if they got all 20. A supposedly independent commission was formed to settle the dispute, but it was deadlocked for a long time. Finally, a deal was struck to end Reconstruction. The result was that this dirty deal caused the one abstaining member of the commission to throw his vote to Republican Rutherford B. Hayes. The result of this dirty deal was that the commission awarded all 20 disputed electoral votes to Hayes… which resulted in Hays winning the electoral college with one vote; that is, no votes to spare. The other time… the third time? (Actually it was the first.) In the election of 1800, Jefferson and Aaron Burr got the same number of votes. Before the 12th amendment (1802), electors each had two votes but they were undifferentiated. The Democratic-Republicans forgot to withhold a vote for Burr, who was supposed to become VP. The election was thrown to the House of Representatives, which was deadlocked for 36 ballots. At last, one of the delegations supporting Burr (doing this deliberately to frustrate Jefferson), had ONE MEMBER who switched to voting for Jefferson, thus allowing Jefferson to finally declare victory. So that would be the first example of how one vote — in this case a Congressman’s — made someone president.

No. But it’s not the simple, and there are issues that need to be understood. To be precise, we have to distinguish between an election being decided by a single vote, which could happen, and an election being decided correctly by a single vote, which is extremely unlikely to happen. After all, not all votes are correctly counted. There is a (very small) amount of voter fraud, a (somewhat larger) amount of election fraud, and (a small but still too large amount) of vote mis-counting, i.e. incorrect handwriting matches, damaged ballots, “hanging chads,” improperly but not maliciously discarded ballots, etc. These miscounts, in effect, contribute random noise to the vote. Given that there is random noise in the vote, there is an implicit signal to noise ratio in the vote. For us to be confident that the vote is correct, the margin of victory must exceed the noise floor by some significant margin, say 2 standard deviations, i.e. a 95% chance that the victory was not just random. It’s clear enough that in most Presidential elections, the margin of victory is big enough to be quite confident of the result, but that’s not always the case. In other words, a very close election will have a victor, but who that is might just be a statistical fluke, and not reflect an actual majority of the voters. The closest Presidential election in recent history was in 2000, when the vote was so close that Florida state law required a recount. Bush won Florida by 537 votes, a margin of 0.009%. We do not know what the “noise floor” in the Florida count was, but most observers believe that if Florida had completed its statewide recount, which was stopped by the Supreme Court, the result of the election would have been a victory for Gore instead of for Bush.[1] That is pretty strong evidence that the Bush victory was a statistical fluke caused by random problems with the vote. Footnotes[1] Bush v. Gore - Wikipedia

Mathematically it is possible. The probability of the unique circumstances which could make this happen is very nearly zero. It would require a tie in the sum of EC vote totals of all the other jurisdictions and a one vote victory in the one remaining jurisdiction. This probability is only slightly higher than that of Trump running a sub two hour marathon.

If you mean in terms of the overall popular vote, then no, no president has ever won by a single vote. It could be argued, however, that Andrew Johnson retained the presidency by a single vote when one of the senators refused to vote for his impeachment. That would be the closest thing to “winning” by a single vote.

Consider the number of ballots cast in the United States Consider the number of unreadable ballots, whether ambiguous, unreadable, or flat out incorrectly marked Consider the number of mail-in ballots lost, late, or lacking proper postmark, signature, etc., collectively referred to as invalidated I’ve described the counting of ballots as only countable to a margin of error, defined by the limitations enumerated above. I’ve found the backlash absolutely amazing … it brings the most angry responses I’ve ever read that a margin of error in counting ballots is a falsehood … “EACH AND EVERY CAST BALLOT IN AN ELECTION CAN BE COUNTED, and nothing less can be considered acceptable”. The margin of error in counting ballots makes the notion of a single vote difference deciding an election TOO CLOSE TO CALL … it’s within the margin of error and indeterminable. As a practicing engineer / scientist, one of my fields of specialization is instrumentation. I consider this not merely an opinion, but a provable scientific fact. But I’m comfortable with anyone that prefers calling this a wrong-minded or ignorant opinion just fine … I’ve seen the replies before, and I’ve no intent to respond to flames or debate the issue. So, if this flies in the face of your perspective, you have my permission to ignore.
